p.verse: 1The word of the Lord that came to Micah the Moreshite ​– ​what he saw regarding Samaria and Jerusalem in the days of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.

poem.verse: 2Listen, all you peoples;

poetryblock.poem: pay attention, earth and everyone in it!
The Lord God will be a witness against you,
the Lord, from his holy temple.

poem.verse: 3Look, the Lord is leaving his place

poetryblock.poem: and coming down to trample
the heights of the earth.

poem.verse: 4The mountains will melt beneath him,

poetryblock.poem: and the valleys will split apart,
like wax near a fire,
like water cascading down a mountainside.

poem.verse: 5All this will happen because of Jacob’s rebellion

poetryblock.poem: and the sins of the house of Israel.
What is the rebellion of Jacob?
Isn’t it Samaria?
And what is the high place of Judah?
Isn’t it Jerusalem?

poem.verse: 6Therefore, I will make Samaria

poetryblock.poem: a heap of ruins in the countryside,
a planting area for a vineyard.
I will roll her stones into the valley
and expose her foundations.

poem.verse: 7All her carved images will be smashed to pieces;

poetryblock.poem: all her wages will be burned in the fire,
and I will destroy all her idols.
Since she collected the wages of a prostitute,
they will be used again for a prostitute.

poem.verse: 8Because of this I will lament and wail;

poetryblock.poem: I will walk barefoot and naked.
I will howl like the jackals
and mourn like ostriches.

poem.verse: 9For her wound is incurable

poetryblock.poem: and has reached even Judah;
it has approached my people’s city gate,
as far as Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 10Don’t announce it in Gath,

poetryblock.poem: don’t weep at all.
Roll in the dust in Beth-leaphrah.

poem.verse: 11Depart in shameful nakedness,

poetryblock.poem: you residents of Shaphir;
the residents of Zaanan will not come out.
Beth-ezel is lamenting;
its support is taken from you.

poem.verse: 12Though the residents of Maroth

poetryblock.poem: anxiously wait for something good,
disaster has come from the Lord
to the gate of Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 13Harness the horses to the chariot,

poetryblock.poem: you residents of Lachish.
This was the beginning of sin for Daughter Zion
because Israel’s acts of rebellion can be traced to you.

poem.verse: 14Therefore, send farewell gifts to Moresheth-gath;

poetryblock.poem: the houses of Achzib are a deception
to the kings of Israel.

poem.verse: 15I will again bring a conqueror

poetryblock.poem: against you who live in Mareshah.
The nobility of Israel will come to Adullam.

poem.verse: 16Shave yourselves bald and cut off your hair

poetryblock.poem: in sorrow for your precious children;
make yourselves as bald as an eagle,
for they have been taken from you into exile.

poem.verse: 1Woe to those who dream up wickedness

poetryblock.poem: and prepare evil plans on their beds!
At morning light they accomplish it
because the power is in their hands.

poem.verse: 2They covet fields and seize them;

poetryblock.poem: they also take houses.
They deprive a man of his home,
a person of his inheritance.
I am now planning a disaster
against this nation;
you cannot free your necks from it.
Then you will not walk so proudly
because it will be an evil time.

poem.verse: 4In that day one will take up a taunt against you

poetryblock.poem: and lament mournfully, saying,
‘We are totally ruined!
He measures out the allotted land of my people.
How he removes it from me!
He allots our fields to traitors.’

poem.verse: 5Therefore, there will be no one

poetryblock.poem: in the assembly of the Lord
to divide the land by casting lots.

poem.verse: 6‘Abandon your preaching,’ they preach.

poetryblock.poem: ‘They should not preach these things;
shame will not overtake us.’

poem.verse: 7House of Jacob, should it be asked,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Is the Spirit of the Lord impatient?
Are these the things he does? ’
Don’t my words bring good
to the one who walks uprightly?

poem.verse: 8But recently my people have risen up

poetryblock.poem: like an enemy:
You strip off the splendid robe
from those who are passing through confidently,
like those returning from war.

poem.verse: 9You force the women of my people

poetryblock.poem: out of their comfortable homes,
and you take my blessing
from their children for ever.

poem.verse: 10Get up and leave,

poetryblock.poem: for this is not your place of rest
because defilement brings destruction –
a grievous destruction!

poem.verse: 11If a man comes

poetryblock.poem: and utters empty lies ​–
‘I will preach to you about wine and beer’ –
he would be just the preacher for this people!

poem.verse: 12I will indeed gather all of you, Jacob;

poetryblock.poem: I will collect the remnant of Israel.
I will bring them together like sheep in a pen,
like a flock in the middle of its pasture.
It will be noisy with people.

poem.verse: 13One who breaks open the way

poetryblock.poem: will advance before them;
they will break out, pass through the city gate,
and leave by it.
Their King will pass through before them,
the Lord as their leader.

poem.verse: 1Then I said, ‘Now listen, leaders of Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: you rulers of the house of Israel.
Aren’t you supposed to know what is just?

poem.verse: 2You hate good and love evil.

poetryblock.poem: You tear off people’s skin
and strip their flesh from their bones.

poem.verse: 3You eat the flesh of my people

poetryblock.poem: after you strip their skin from them
and break their bones.
You chop them up
like flesh for the cooking pot,
like meat in a cauldron.’

poem.verse: 4Then they will cry out to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but he will not answer them.
He will hide his face from them at that time
because of the crimes they have committed.

poem.verse: 5This is what the Lord says

poetryblock.poem: concerning the prophets
who lead my people astray,
who proclaim peace
when they have food to sink their teeth into
but declare war against the one
who puts nothing in their mouths.

poem.verse: 6Therefore, it will be night for you –

poetryblock.poem: without visions;
it will grow dark for you –
without divination.
The sun will set on these prophets,
and the daylight will turn black over them.

poem.verse: 7Then the seers will be ashamed

poetryblock.poem: and the diviners disappointed.
They will all cover their mouths
because there will be no answer from God.

poem.verse: 8As for me, however, I am filled with power

poetryblock.poem: by the Spirit of the Lord,
with justice and courage,
to proclaim to Jacob his rebellion
and to Israel his sin.

poem.verse: 9Listen to this, leaders of the house of Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: you rulers of the house of Israel,
who abhor justice
and pervert everything that is right,

poem.verse: 10who build Zion with bloodshed

poetryblock.poem: and Jerusalem with injustice.

poem.verse: 11Her leaders issue rulings for a bribe,

poetryblock.poem: her priests teach for payment,
and her prophets practise divination for silver.
Yet they lean on the Lord, saying,
‘Isn’t the Lord among us?
No disaster will overtake us.’

poem.verse: 12Therefore, because of you,

poetryblock.poem: Zion will be ploughed like a field,
Jerusalem will become ruins,
and the temple’s mountain
will be a high thicket.

chapter.head1: The Lord’s Rule from Restored Zion

poem.verse: 1In the last days

poetryblock.poem: the mountain of the Lord’s house
will be established
at the top of the mountains
and will be raised above the hills.
Peoples will stream to it,

poem.verse: 2and many nations will come and say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Come, let’s go up to the mountain of the Lord,
to the house of the God of Jacob.
He will teach us about his ways
So that we may walk in his paths.’
For instruction will go out of Zion
and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 3He will settle disputes among many peoples

poetryblock.poem: and provide arbitration for strong nations
that are far away.
They will beat their swords into ploughs
and their spears into pruning knives.
Nation will not take up the sword against nation,
and they will never again train for war.

poem.verse: 4But each person will sit under his grapevine

poetryblock.poem: and under his fig tree
with no one to frighten him.
For the mouth of the Lord of Armies
has spoken.

poem.verse: 5Though all the peoples walk

poetryblock.poem: in the name of their own gods,
we will walk in the name of the Lord our God
for ever and ever.

poem.verse: 6On that day –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
I will assemble the lame
and gather the scattered,
those I have injured.

poem.verse: 7I will make the lame into a remnant,

poetryblock.poem: those far removed into a strong nation.
Then the Lord will reign over them in Mount Zion
from this time on and for ever.

poem.verse: 8And you, watchtower for the flock,

poetryblock.poem: fortified hill of Daughter Zion,
the former rule will come to you;
sovereignty will come to Daughter Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 9Now, why are you shouting loudly?

poetryblock.poem: Is there no king with you?
Has your counsellor perished,
so that anguish grips you like a woman in labour?

poem.verse: 10Writhe and cry out, Daughter Zion,

poetryblock.poem: like a woman in labour,
for now you will leave the city
and camp in the open fields.
You will go to Babylon;
there you will be rescued;
there the Lord will redeem you
from the grasp of your enemies!

poem.verse: 11Many nations have now assembled against you;

poetryblock.poem: they say, ‘Let her be defiled,
and let us feast our eyes on Zion.’

poem.verse: 12But they do not know the Lord’s intentions

poetryblock.poem: or understand his plan,
that he has gathered them
like sheaves to the threshing-floor.

poem.verse: 13Rise and thresh, Daughter Zion,

poetryblock.poem: for I will make your horns iron
and your hooves bronze
so that you can crush many peoples.
Then you will set apart their plunder
for the Lord,
their wealth for the Lord of the whole earth.

chapter.head1: From Defeated Ruler to Conquering King

poem.verse: 1Now, daughter who is under attack,

poetryblock.poem: you slash yourself in grief;
a siege is set against us!
They are striking the judge of Israel
on the cheek with a rod.

poem.verse: 2Bethlehem Ephrathah,

poetryblock.poem: you are small among the clans of Judah;
one will come from you
to be ruler over Israel for me.
His origin is from antiquity,
from ancient times.

poem.verse: 3Therefore, Israel will be abandoned until the time

poetryblock.poem: when she who is in labour has given birth;
then the rest of the ruler’s brothers will return
to the people of Israel.

poem.verse: 4He will stand and shepherd them

poetryblock.poem: in the strength of the Lord,
in the majestic name of the Lord his God.
They will live securely,
for then his greatness will extend
to the ends of the earth.

poem.verse: 5He will be their peace.

poetryblock.poem: When Assyria invades our land,
when it marches against our fortresses,
we will raise against it seven shepherds,
even eight leaders of men.

poem.verse: 6They will shepherd the land of Assyria with the sword,

poetryblock.poem: the land of Nimrod with a drawn blade.
So he will rescue us from Assyria
when it invades our land,
when it marches against our territory.

poem.verse: 7Then the remnant of Jacob

poetryblock.poem: will be among many peoples
like dew from the Lord,
like showers on the grass,
which do not wait for anyone
or linger for mankind.

poem.verse: 8Then the remnant of Jacob

poetryblock.poem: will be among the nations, among many peoples,
like a lion among animals of the forest,
like a young lion among flocks of sheep,
which tramples and tears as it passes through,
and there is no one to rescue them.

poem.verse: 9Your hand will be lifted up against your adversaries,

poetryblock.poem: and all your enemies will be destroyed.

poem.verse: 10In that day –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
I will remove your horses from you
and wreck your chariots.

poem.verse: 11I will remove the cities of your land

poetryblock.poem: and tear down all your fortresses.

poem.verse: 12I will remove sorceries from your hands,

poetryblock.poem: and you will not have any more fortune-tellers.

poem.verse: 13I will remove your carved images

poetryblock.poem: and sacred pillars from you
so that you will no longer worship
the work of your hands.

poem.verse: 14I will pull up the Asherah poles from among you

poetryblock.poem: and demolish your cities.

poem.verse: 15I will take vengeance in anger and wrath

poetryblock.poem: against the nations that have not obeyed me.

p.verse: 1Now listen to what the Lord is saying:

poetryblock.poem: Rise, plead your case before the mountains,
and let the hills hear your complaint.

poem.verse: 2Listen to the Lord’s lawsuit,

poetryblock.poem: you mountains and enduring foundations of the earth,
because the Lord has a case against his people,
and he will argue it against Israel.

poem.verse: 3My people, what have I done to you,

poetryblock.poem: or how have I wearied you?
Testify against me!

poem.verse: 4Indeed, I brought you up from the land of Egypt

poetryblock.poem: and redeemed you from that place of slavery.
I sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam ahead of you.

poem.verse: 5My people,

poetryblock.poem: remember what King Balak of Moab proposed,
what Balaam son of Beor answered him,
and what happened from the Acacia Grove to Gilgal,
so that you may acknowledge
the Lord’s righteous acts.

poem.verse: 6What should I bring before the Lord

poetryblock.poem: when I come to bow before God on high?
Should I come before him with burnt offerings,
with year-old calves?

poem.verse: 7Would the Lord be pleased with thousands of rams

poetryblock.poem: or with ten thousand streams of oil?
Should I give my firstborn for my transgression,
the offspring of my body for my own sin?

poem.verse: 8Mankind, he has told each of you what is good

poetryblock.poem: and what it is the Lord requires of you:
to act justly,
to love faithfulness,
and to walk humbly with your God.

poem.verse: 9The voice of the Lord calls out to the city

poetryblock.poem: (and it is wise to fear your name):
‘Pay attention to the rod
and the one who ordained it.

poem.verse: 10Are there still the treasures of wickedness

poetryblock.poem: and the accursed short measure
in the house of the wicked?

poem.verse: 11Can I excuse wicked scales

poetryblock.poem: or bags of deceptive weights?

poem.verse: 12For the wealthy of the city are full of violence,

poetryblock.poem: and its residents speak lies;
the tongues in their mouths are deceitful.

poem.verse: 13‘As a result, I have begun to strike you severely,

poetryblock.poem: bringing desolation because of your sins.

poem.verse: 14You will eat but not be satisfied,

poetryblock.poem: for there will be hunger within you.
What you acquire, you cannot save,
and what you do save,
I will give to the sword.

poem.verse: 15You will sow but not reap;

poetryblock.poem: you will press olives
but not anoint yourself with oil;
and you will tread grapes
but not drink the wine.

poem.verse: 16The statutes of Omri

poetryblock.poem: and all the practices of Ahab’s house
have been observed;
you have followed their policies.
Therefore, I will make you a desolate place
and the city’s residents an object of contempt;
you will bear the scorn of my people.’

poem.verse: 1How sad for me!

poetryblock.poem: For I am like one who –
when the summer fruit has been gathered
after the gleaning of the grape harvest –
finds no grape cluster to eat,
no early fig, which I crave.

poem.verse: 2Faithful people have vanished from the land;

poetryblock.poem: there is no one upright among the people.
All of them wait in ambush to shed blood;
they hunt each other with a net.

poem.verse: 3Both hands are good at accomplishing evil:

poetryblock.poem: the official and the judge demand a bribe;
when the powerful man communicates his evil desire,
they plot it together.

poem.verse: 4The best of them is like a briar;

poetryblock.poem: the most upright is worse than a hedge of thorns.
The day of your watchmen,
the day of your punishment, is coming;
at this time their panic is here.

poem.verse: 5Do not rely on a friend;

poetryblock.poem: don’t trust in a close companion.
Seal your mouth
from the woman who lies in your arms.

poem.verse: 6Surely a son considers his father a fool,

poetryblock.poem: a daughter opposes her mother,
and a daughter-in-law is against her mother-in-law;
a man’s enemies are the men of his own household.

poem.verse: 7But I will look to the Lord;

poetryblock.poem: I will wait for the God of my salvation.
My God will hear me.

poem.verse: 8Do not rejoice over me, my enemy!

poetryblock.poem: Though I have fallen, I will stand up;
though I sit in darkness,
the Lord will be my light.

poem.verse: 9Because I have sinned against him,

poetryblock.poem: I must endure the Lord’s fury
until he champions my cause
and establishes justice for me.
He will bring me into the light;
I will see his salvation.

poem.verse: 10Then my enemy will see,

poetryblock.poem: and she will be covered with shame,
the one who said to me,
‘Where is the Lord your God? ’
My eyes will look at her in triumph;
at that time she will be trampled
like mud in the streets.

poem.verse: 11A day will come for rebuilding your walls;

poetryblock.poem: on that day your boundary will be extended.

poem.verse: 12On that day people will come to you

poetryblock.poem: from Assyria and the cities of Egypt,
even from Egypt to the River Euphrates
and from sea to sea
and mountain to mountain.

poem.verse: 13Then the earth will become a wasteland

poetryblock.poem: because of its inhabitants
and as a result of their actions.

poem.verse: 14Shepherd your people with your staff,

poetryblock.poem: the flock that is your possession.
They live alone in a woodland
surrounded by pastures.
Let them graze in Bashan and Gilead
as in ancient times.

poem.verse: 15I will perform miracles for them

poetryblock.poem: as in the days of your exodus
from the land of Egypt.

poem.verse: 16Nations will see and be ashamed

poetryblock.poem: of all their power.
They will put their hands over their mouths,
and their ears will become deaf.

poem.verse: 17They will lick the dust like a snake;

poetryblock.poem: they will come trembling out of their hiding places
like reptiles slithering on the ground.
They will tremble in the presence of the Lord our God;
they will stand in awe of you.

poem.verse: 18Who is a God like you,

poetryblock.poem: forgiving iniquity and passing over rebellion
for the remnant of his inheritance?
He does not hold on to his anger for ever
because he delights in faithful love.

poem.verse: 19He will again have compassion on us;

poetryblock.poem: he will vanquish our iniquities.
You will cast all our sins
into the depths of the sea.

poem.verse: 20You will show loyalty to Jacob

poetryblock.poem: and faithful love to Abraham,
as you swore to our ancestors
from days long ago.
